review_title: Great company, but avoid school-bases program
job_title: Mental Health Professional in Havertown, PA
pros: Collaboration, great supervisors, sense of community, supportive co-workers and supervisors
cons: Would not recommend the school-based program. You are expected to act like a district employee without the pay of a district employee. The work is extremely stressful physically and mentally. High burnout rate. Most of the time is spent chasing children around or doing restraints. There is little to no mental health work with this job. If you’re looking for a true mental health position, look elsewhere. Your qualifications will not be put to good use in this position.

job_title: Child Outpatient Therapist in Havertown, PA
pros: CGRC is a great place for entry-level clinicians and clinicians with much experience alike. CGRC creates a caring and communicative environment for new clinicians to mold and shape their practice and for experienced clincians to have the support they need as well.
cons: Working for a non-profit often raises concerns of salary, while CGRC is a friendly and loving environment, many of the staff have difficulty keeping the part time positions because of the lower pay and no benefits offered to part time staff.

review_title: No support from managers or directors for school based workers

job_title: Licensed Professional Counselor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: gain experience right out of school

review_title: Positive things are coming - the organization heart is in the right place, you make it what you want it to be!
pros: The work/life balance is fantastic, from an administrative team perspective, the organization is incredibly supportive of any crisis you may have personally. They encourage balance (as long as you get your projects done of course). Employees in administration are dedicated to their work and there is opportunity to collaborate with really smart people and learn from each other. CGRC likes to invest in their employees and, once you build a strong foundation with your team, keep you around.
cons: Working in behavioral health in this political budget climate is difficult. There have been many changes in reimbursement rates and the agency has felt the struggles of that. People can feel stressed by the pressures of financial strain from the government and there have been a lot of transitions in the last few months with new executive management and program shifting, which can feel stressful. And even good change feels scary. As with any non-profit, there's a lot to do every day, but that can be exciting as well. The company isn't going anywhere, and many people feel confident that this new stage of CGRC will be quite positive (if slightly different).

job_title: Mental Health Professional in Havertown, PA
pros: Family FIrst is a great place to do great clinical work with excellent support and highly qualified clinical supervision. There is a company wide commitment to helping clinicians get licensed and that is great, it makes it easy to talk about and easy to do. The supervisors and coworkers in Family First are exceptional. There is a committee to support staff activities and it is easy to get help when you need it. The compensation is pretty good for mental health with the productivity incentives. The work is intense, and the treatment modality used really works. Patients get better. The company supports flexibility and values employees' work life balance. I never have to feel bad if I need to get to a meeting or the dr.
cons: Family First is now a completely community based department and, although there are desks available for work at the office, it is not as easy as it once was to chill out for a few moments. Even with a storage drawer at the office it is harder to stay organized and relaxed than when everyone had a desk. However, mileage reimbursement went way up now that I charge from home.

review_title: A generally positive experience for entry level clinician.
pros:
- supportive co workers
- get great experience working with kids and families
- looks good on a resume
- many of the supervisors are very caring and experienced
- learn popular medical records system
- internship opportunities
- helps you learn to work independently
- offers a variety of mental health and therapy positions in varying departments so you can always find a job that fits your schedule
- never a lack of clients
- often have flexible hours for various positions
cons:
- supervisors are over worked and often don't have the time you or they would like for supervision
- full time/salaried positions are few and far between
- face to face hours are the only billable hours, little to no compensation for time spent planning sessions or doing paperwork
- some offices can be cliqueish
- Interns may have quite a bit of down time depending on schedule
- not always with time spent on full training of new employees
- high turnover rates

review_title: Not what Community Mental Health should be. It once was. It has lost it's mission and values no matter what they say.
pros: Flexibility, work family life is very good. If you have the right supervisor you will get lots of support and personal attention.
cons: Leadership is nepotistic and concerned only about money. Client care is no longer a priority. Making money is more important than retaining staff and serving clients.  Clinicians live in a fear based state to produce which negatively impacts morale. Did I mention NEPOTISM? If you choose to work there be prepared to never speak the truth.

review_title: A Review from the new CEO...
job_title: President/Chief Executive Officer in Havertown, PA
pros:
My name is Colleen McNichol, President/CEO of Child Guidance Resource Centers (CGRC) as of January 4.  After reading some of the reviews on this site, I felt compelled to post about my experiences at CGRC.

I have been employed at CGRC for 25 years.  I began my employment as the Executive Assistant to the CEO in 1991.  Throughout the years, I have been promoted several times to various management positions within the organization:  Manager of HR, VP of HR and Adult Services, COO, and now CEO.  CGRC has ALWAYS been an organization dedicated to providing the highest quality behavioral healthcare services to children, families, and adults.  I believe our clinical staff to be the absolute best in the industry, bar none, and I believe wholeheartedly they are the reason for our continued success.  

Despite what some have posted, I speak for the entire leadership team when I say that CGRC values its employees above all else.  Despite tremendous growth over the past 10 years along with significant financial challenges over the past 3 years, we remain committed to being a family-friendly organization that supports work/life balance.  We support our employees, and we work hard to ensure that they are recognized and rewarded to the extent we can, given our economic challenges.  We are committed to providing staff development and career planning, and we try to promote staff from within at all times.  Are we without organizational challenges?  No.  The past few years have been difficult for our industry, which has led to significant financial challenges to CGRC. We have responded to these challenges with innovation, creativity, and flexibility, with our commitment to providing the highest quality behavioral healthcare services to children, families, and adults guiding all actions and decisions.
cons: We had to “rightsize” the organization this year.  Although the phrase “rightsizing” has been used in some organizations as a euphemism for “downsizing” to make it seem more pleasant than it is, they are not at all the same thing. In rightsizing, we focus on the future and where the organization is headed, and how we can create an organizational structure that is conducive to the successful fulfillment of our mission.  During our rightsizing process, several members of the CGRC family had to leave us.  The decisions on which employees would be impacted were not made lightly or impulsively. We had been discussing such changes for at least a year and explored all other options before taking such actions.   Unfortunately, the rightsizing initiative coupled with our continued efforts to reduce expenses and improve revenues so that we could improve our financial position caused some strain on the organization’s culture.  Some staff, current and former, concluded that the organization was focused on the bottom line and not our staff or clients as a result of our actions.  This could not be further from the truth.  ALL of our actions are guided by our commitment to serving our Mission, which can ONLY be accomplished if we offer the same commitment and dedication to our employees.  As a result of our attention to the fiscal health of CGRC, we were able to design and implement a reorganization of our leadership structure throughout the organization that positions us to be the right size and shape for optimum effectiveness and efficiency in serving the Mission of our organization and achieving our strategic goals for many years to come.

job_title: Blended Case Manager in Coatesville, PA
pros: Can work from home, lots of PTO
cons: From the start the training lacked consistency and was completely unprepared when I started taking client. Management was extremely unsupportive and really did not care about the employees. Every week there were different expectations and there was constantly different monogamous requirements for things that were unimportant. Upper management was telling co workers to do things a certain way and other management would tell other co workers to do It a different way, consistency was extremely lacking within the company.  Pretty much was a dumping person for clients families, and clients were not held to follow non compliance policies, even though we were stressed about the company policies. Overall, was not worth It to work for this company.

review_title: Coworkers are great but upper level management out of touch
job_title: Mental Health Professional in Havertown, PA
pros: Flexible schedule, not much micromanaging, good pto, focus on self care (at least in family first)
cons: Pay is bad and no raises for 2+ years - not even COLAs, which essential equals a pay cut. They also cut retirement contributions by a percentage pt. Health benefits for spouse or family are cost prohibitive.

pros: Only pros for me were that I could work my own days and hours and I could do my notes on my time at home.
cons: Unpleasant work environment, suspected due to being part-time...did not feel part of the team or accepted by full-time staff.  Supervision/supervisor only interested in numbers, not quality of care provided to clients.  Also, that person was resentful and a back stabber when I quit.  Pay not so great for the amount of time required to do all of the necessary documentation and travel.

review_title: Case manager- worked there in 2000.The best experience of my life and the reason I went back to school for my BA in psyc
pros: The reason why is to help children with the same experiences I passed and learned from .To share that things will always get better.
cons: Challenges are that there are always new things to learn because all children are different but willing to learn and experience.

review_title: I love working here, you get great flexibility with your work hours, and the other employees are very friendly.
pros: Flexible work hours, very good pay, nonprofit organization that works with children and families with mental illness. The upper management is very kind and understanding. I enjoy coming to work every day.
cons: I honestly have nothing bad to say about this company. There really is nothing bad that I have to say about this company.

job_title: Mental Health Worker (Adult Services) in Havertown, PA
pros:
Flexible
You can work at different sites
Clients are enjoyable to be around
Easy job
cons:
Favoritism
No advancement
Co-workers make your job difficult with laziness and bad attitudes
Management is slow in implementing change and disciplining staff
Disorganized
Poor decision making regarding clients
Do not always have the clients interest at heart

pros: Because the overall culture of the agency is horrible, it forces employees to form supportive relationships with one another. As a supervisor I enjoyed working with and meeting new employees.
cons: The agency as a whole lacks focus and appears to have lost sight of their mission. Management focuses heavily on numbers and budget and very little on supporting and training staff. Upper Management are out of touch with the needs of their employees and seem to only focus on projects that they think will lead them to the next pay out. There is a great deal of nepotism, back biting and downright lying that goes on in upper management. Middle management staff carry the same negative and unproductive attitude to direct line staff who are often subject to blame for outcomes beyond their control. The BHRS department is and has been poorly managed for years and continues to have a high supervisor and clinician turnover. I have witnessed many staff from this department be targeted, harassed and fired for standing up for themselves or for the truth. Clients and families are made to believe that certain resources are available which is not true. Clients are placed on long wait lists while the department scrambles to hire new staff. The directors of the delco location are horrible and have been the cause of so many people leaving or transferring to another department. They do not value their employees are only look for individuals to be "YES MEN" to their faulty suggestion. Overall, this place seems to be going down hill.  They are losing money left and right and I've experienced disconnected phones and company websites down. Looks like bills aren't getting paid either. If you are a potential employee or consumer, your needs will probably be better served with a smaller agency that still puts client care and employee retention at the top of their priority list.

review_title: Executive managment needs a lot of work
pros: Wealth of experience to gain.
cons: Been working here for more than 2 year and all I can say it that Executive management need to get their act together. I don't see myself here very long.

pros: Supportive environment with training opportunities and collaboration with coworkers/supervisor on weekly basis. Friendly coworkers, flexible schedule, good benefits.

review_title: Part-time BHRS employee for last four years

cons: BHRS- full-time position is virtually impossible to maintain. Part-time lacks benefits. High turn-over rate. Current lack of agency support for professional licensure.
